div.p: Juggling school, family, and career is a challenging, but worthwhile task.
However, it doesn't have to be a chore.
While appearing simplistic, there are some very basic, commonsense approaches
to maintaining a healthy balance.
It's important to take the time to be good to yourself.
Remember the basics things required for good health...diet, sleep, and exercise.
While being necessary for your overall wellbeing, they help to keep you
at the top of your game academically.
Look around you, particularly where you study.
It's much easier, and more pleasant, to study where you're comfortable.
For some that might be in at a desk in a well-lit room.
For others it might be stretched out on the living room floor.
Plan when and how you're going to study.
Will it be after dinner?
After the children are in bed?
During a lunch break?
Planning will help you to not study any longer than is necessary.
Acknowledge you have another life-- family, career, hobbies-- things of importance to you.
Come to terms with the realization you can't always do it all.
Learn what's important when.
You may be able to delegate some responsibilities
when you find yourself too busy.
This does not admit defeat.
It's just an admission that you're human and like all of use you need
to make adjustments from time to time.
Along the way, take time to recognize your achievements,
whether that be completing an important task at work on time, acing a biology final,
or simply remembering to take out the garbage without being reminded.
You may find yourself a bit overwhelmed upon returning to school
or going to school for the first time.
Learning how to manage your time will help here.
Just some basics: keep a calendar, write things down.
You're going to be busy.
Don't rely on keeping it all in your head while trying to get other stuff in there,
like mathematical formulas, management strategies, rules for writing.
Try to establish a routine.
But, don't be unrealistic.
Reading or studying for six hours on a Saturday so Sunday is free may sound like a good plan.
It's not effective in practice for several reasons.
While getting into a routine is good, take time to reflect on how that routine,
how your time management, is working or not.
Don't be afraid to make adjustments along way.
